paragraphs: This evening I experimented with running dMagnetic is it's sixel mode. Sixel was an early bitmap graphics format that was used on DEC VT terminals. So far I have only managed to get the required VT340 mode working through xterm using the command xterm -ti vt340. The sixel graphics look pretty good but unfortunately kitty, the terminal emulator I usually use, does not support it. I attach the previous scene from Jinxster rendered in sixel mode.

Back to the game, Jinxster is interesting from what I have played so far. It seems to incorporate elements of magical realism, a good parser and a wry sense of humour. I am hoping to get the opportunity this week to spend some more time with it.

images.alt: A scene of passengers on a bus rendered in the terminal using sixel graphics, while playing the Jinxter IF game with dMagnetic.

paragraphs: I had fun yesterday playing Plundered Hearts on a train journey across the UK, it's a riveting story ! It was also good to get experience with using IFMapper. This morning I watched an interesting YouTube video by Kim Justice on the interactive fiction games created by the Magnetic Scrolls studio. These games were text based but also incorporated beautiful artwork. I was interested on how to play their games on Linux and found an interpreter called dMagnetic (https://dettus.net/dMagnetic/). I could find no Arch Linux packages available but I was able to download the source package from the website and compile it without any issues. I am running dMagnetic from the terminal in its utf video mode dMagnetic -mag jinxter.mag -gfx jinxter.gfx -vmode utf, which provides a good render for a terminal application. There is also a GTK version available, which I may try at a later date.
The gfx and mag game files required by dMagnetic can be obtained from the Magnetic Scrolls Memorial site (https://msmemorial.if-legends.org/magnetic.php).

images.alt: A scene of passengers on a bus rendered in the terminal using utf characters, while playing the Jinxter IF game with dMagnetic.

text: An interesting clip from the BBC show The Computer Programme, a favourite from my childhood. Here Dave Lebling is debugging Spellbreaker with Amy Briggs (the Plundered Hearts creator). I think that is a DEC VT Terminal which Dave is using to code in ZIL (Infocom's implementation language), it looks very stylish.

paragraphs: I have been playing the Infocom adventure Enchanter with Frotz over the last fortnight. I wanted a basic terminal based mapping tool where I could keep track of the rooms I had visited. Rather than a grid based map I thought to choose the terminal based mind mapping tool h-m-m (https://github.com/nadrad/h-m-m). This is a simple tool that allows you to create nodes and connect them together. I found it easy to use and it worked well for my needs. I created a node for each room and connected them together as I explored the game. I also added notes to each node to help me remember important details. One feature of h-m-m is the ability to export the graph as an html file ( /files/enchanter_map.html).

Today I made the decision to move over to using the IFMapper tool (https://ggarra13.github.io/ifmapper/en/start.html). This is a more specialised tool for mapping interactive fiction games. The main reason to migrate was that although h-m-m worked well on Arch Linux, I found it difficult to install on other distros. Having reached Expert Enchanter rank on Enchanter I have decided to start a new text adventure and map, this time choosing Plundered Hearts.

I picked up an RP2350 Pico 2 microcontroller from the Raspberry Pi store in Cambridge last weekend with a plan to combine it with an HDMI display and mechanical keyboard I had spare. I mounted the RP2350 in an Olimex rp2040-pico-pc motherboard and flashed the Pico 2 with the Picomite BASIC core (https://geoffg.net - the PicoMiteHDMIUSB core). Although this core is compatible with the rp2040-pico-pc board I did have to blind set the HDMI support option using the keyboard via the option reset olimexusb command. This set the necessary options to connect to the display via the Olimex HDMI port, after which I reset the Olimex board.

The https://thebackshed.com forum provided useful information on how to implement this setup. For software I found the Clockwork Pi forum useful. As the deck was running similar BASIC firmware to the Clockwork Pi PicoCalc handheld device, I was able to use the software written for this platform.

paragraphs: An interesting You Tube film from 1972 of the Barbican estate in London. The Barbican is a brutalist residential complex in the centre of London, containing shops, gardens, restaurants, theatres and gallery spaces. I worked nearby during the several years I lived in London and would spend my lunch breaks either in the garden, restaurant or basement. Shown here, the strikingly orange painted basement always provided a quiet, calm space from the busy city. I would sit here coding my own projects or playing Discworld MUD.

In the evenings it was a music and theatre venue. I remember seeing the Residents play here with my dear friend Andy. On Fridays, I would treat myself to a roast duck dinner in the restaurant and sometimes a book from it's bookshop. I never returned after the Pandemic, maybe it had changed as I had. I would soon leave London and start a new chapter of my life.

images.alt: The orange basement of the Barbican Centre

text: A small project to create a storage display shelf for my wall. I found a bare wooden shelf unit from a craft outlet and stained it for a mahogany look. I also gave the shelves a coat of linseed oil to help preserve them. I am quite happy with the results.

images.alt: A mahogany display shelf containing ephemera

text: Two creators that have been an inspiration are Carol Shaw (Atari - River Raid) and Amy Briggs (Infocom - Plundered Hearts). I have watched some interesting films about Infocom recently. Text adventures were a significant part of my youth. I would recommend The Infocom documentary, especially as it contains an interview with Amy Briggs.
